titleStmt.title: Articles of peace, entercourse, and commerce concluded in the names of the most high and mighty kings, and princes Iames by the grace of God, King of great Britaine, France, and Ireland, defender of the faith, &c. and Philip the third, King of Spaine, &c. and Albertus and Isabella Clara Eugenia, Archdukes of Austrice, Dukes of Burgundie, &c. In a treatie at London the 18. day of August after the old stile in the yeere of our Lord God 1604. Translated out of Latine into English.
Treaty. 1604 Aug. 18.

In a treatie at London the 18. day of August after the old stile in the yeere of our Lord God 1604. Translated out of Latine into English.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ARTICLES OF PEACE, ENTERCOVRSE, AND Commerce, Concluded in the names of the mo≈øt high and mighty Kings, and Princes IAMES by the grace of GOD, King of great Britaine, France, and Ireland, defender of the faith, &c. And Philip the third, King of Spaine, &c. And Albertus and I≈øabella Clara Eugenia, Archdukes of Austrice, Dukes of Burgundie, &c. In a Treatie at London the 18. day of Augu≈øt after the old Stile in the yeere of our Lord God 1604. ¬∂ Tran≈ølated out of Latine into Engli≈øh.
IMPRINTED AT LONdon by Robert Barker, Printer to the Kings most Excellent Maiestie. ANNO 1605.

figure.figDesc: blazon or coat of arms of the British royal family

list.head: ¬∂ The Commi≈øsioners for the mo≈øt renowned King of great BRITAINE, &c.
list.item: THOMAS Earle of Dor≈øet, Baron of Buckhur≈øt, high Trea≈øurer of England.

CHARLES Earle of Nottingham, Baron Howard of Effingham, chiefe Iu≈øtice, and Ju≈øtice itinerant of all Forre≈øts on this ≈øide Trent, high Admirall of England, and Captaine generall of the Nauies, and Seas of England, Jreland, and the Jles, and Dominions thereof.

CHARLES Earle of Deuon≈øhire, Baron of Mountioy, Lieutenant in the Kingdome of Jreland, Ma≈øter of the Ordinance, Gouernour of the Towne, Jland, & Ca≈øtle of Porte≈ømouth, Knights of the mo≈øt honourable order of the Garter.
HENRY Earle of Northampton, Lord Howard of Marnehill, Lord Warden, and Admirall of the Cinque Ports.
ROBERT Lord ∆≤icount Cranborne, Lord Cecill of E≈øenden, Principall Secretary, Ma≈øter of the Court of Wardes, and Liueries. All Lords of his Maie≈øties Priuie Coun≈øell.

list.head: ¬∂ Commi≈øsioners for the King of Spaine, &c.
list.item: IOHN DE VELASCO Con≈øtable of Ca≈øtile, and Legion, Duke of the Citie of Frias, Earle of Haro, Lord of the Townes of ∆≤illalpand, and Pedra√ßa de la Sierra, Lord of the hou≈øe of ∆≤ela≈øco, and of the ≈øeuen Jnfants of Lara, great Chamberlaine vnto PHILIP the Third, King of Spaine, &c. Coun≈øeller of State and Warre, Pre≈øident of Jtalie.
IOHN BAPTISTA DE TASSIS, Earle of ∆≤illa Mediana, Gentleman of the Kings Chamber, and Postmaster generall in the Kingdoms & dominions of the ≈øaid King.
ALEXANDER ROVIDIVS Profe≈ø≈øor of the Law in the Colledge of Millaine, and Senator of the Prouince of Millaine.

list.head: ¬∂ Commi≈øsioners for the Archdukes.
list.item: CHARLES Prince, and Counte of Aremberge, Knight of the order of the Golden fleece, Coun≈øeller of State; and Admirall generall to the ≈øaid Archdukes.
IOHN RICHARDOT Knight, Pre≈øident of the Priuie Coun≈øell, and Coun≈øeller of State.
LODOVIKE VERREIKEN Knight, Principall Secretary, and Audienciarie.

div.p:
FIr≈øt it is concluded, and accorded, that from this day forward, there ≈øhall bee a good, ≈øincere, true, firme, and perfect Amitie, League, & Peace, to endure for euer, and inuiolably to bee ob≈øerued and kept, as well by Land as Sea, and fre≈øh waters, betwixt the mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, &c. And the mo≈øt renowned King of Spaine, &c. And the mo≈øt renowned Archdukes
of Au≈øtrice, Dukes of Burgundie, &c. and their Heires and Succe≈ø≈øours whom≈øoeuer, their Kingdomes, Countreys, Dominions, Lands, Peoples, Liegemen, and Subiects now being, or which hereafter ≈øhall be, of what≈øoeuer condition, ≈øtate, or degree they are or may be, ≈øo as the ≈øaid Va≈ø≈øals and Subiects from henceforth are each of them to fauour other, and to v≈øe one another with all kind and friendly offices.

div.head: II.
div.p:
ANd that from henceforth all Ho≈øtilitie, and enmitie ≈øhall cea≈øe, and all offences, iniuries or damages which either part (in time of the troubles) hath ≈øu≈øteined by the other, ≈øhalbe taken away and forgotten, in ≈øuch ≈øort, as that hereafter neither partie again≈øt other, for, or vpon occa≈øion of any damages, offences, depredations or ≈øpoyles pa≈øt, may pretend any matter, but that there ≈øhall be a perfect abolition of all and euery of them vntill this pre≈øent day: and that all actions for the ≈øame ≈øhall be held and reputed to be extingui≈øhed, excepting onely ≈øuch depredations
as haue beene committed ≈øince the xxiiij. of April 1603. (becau≈øe of the≈øe an account is to be made:) And each partie ≈øhall hereafter ab≈øtaine from all depredations, offences, and ≈øpoiles as well by Sea as Land, and fre≈øh waters, in what≈øoeuer the Kingdomes, Dominions, Places, or Gouernments of the other: neither ≈øhal the afore≈øaid Princes con≈øent, that any of the grieuances before mentioned, be done by any of their Va≈ø≈øals, Inhabitants, or Subiects: and they ≈øhall al≈øo cau≈øe re≈øtitution to be made of all depredations and ≈øpoiles which hereafter ≈øhall be committed, and of the damages growing by meanes thereof.

div.head: III.
div.p:
ITem, that none of the forenamed Princes, their Heires, or Succe≈ø≈øors who≈øoeuer, by himfelfe or by any others, ≈øhall doe, treat, or attempt any thing again≈øt the other, or again≈øt their Kingdomes, Lands or Dominions what≈øoeuer in any place, on Land or Sea, or in the Ports, or fre≈øh waters, by pretence of any cau≈øe, or vpon any occa≈øion; neither
any of them ≈øhall giue a≈øsi≈øtance or con≈øent vnto any Warre, Coun≈øell, Attempt, or Treaties, had, made, or to be made in the preiudice of either, or again≈øt the other.

div.head: IIII.
div.p: ITem, that neither of the former parties, ≈øhall them≈øelues giue, or ≈øhall con≈øent to be giuen, by any of their Va≈ø≈øals, Subiects, or Inhabitants, aide, fauour, or coun≈øell, directly or indirectly, on Land, Sea, or fre≈øh waters: nor ≈øhall ≈øupply and mini≈øter, nor con≈øent to be ≈øupplyed and mini≈øtred, by their ≈øaid Va≈ø≈øals, Inhabitants and Subiects, vnto the Enemies or Rebels of either part, of what nature or condition ≈øoeuer they be, (whether they ≈øhall inuade the Countreys and Dominions of either of them, or withdraw them≈øelues from their obedience and ≈øubiection) any Souldiers, proui≈øion of Victuals, Monies, In≈øtruments of Warre, Munitions, or what≈øoeuer other aide el≈øe to maintaine Warre.

div.head: V.
div.p: ANd furthermore, the fore≈øaid Princes ≈øhall renounce, as by the tenor of the≈øe Pre≈øents euery of them hath, and doth renounce, what≈øoeuer League, Confederation, Capitulation, and Intelligence made by what manner ≈øoeuer, in the preiudice of the one, or the other, which doth or may repugne again≈øt this Peace, and Concord, and all, and ≈øinguler the Contents thereof: all which and euery of them, ≈øo farre as they doe concerne the effect afore≈øaid, they ≈øhall adnull, and make void, and declare to be of no force, or moment.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
ITem, it is agreed and accorded, that the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned Kings, and Archdukes, ≈øhall take care, that their Subiects ≈øhall from henceforth ab≈øtaine from all force, and wrong doing, and that they likewi≈øe ≈øhall reuoke all Commi≈øsions, and Letters of Repri≈øall, and Mart, or otherwi≈øe conteining Licence to take Prizes, of what condition, or
kinde ≈øoeuer they are, being to the preiudice of the one, or other of the ≈øaid Princes, or of their Subiects, whether the ≈øame haue beene giuen, or graunted by them vnto Subiects, or Inhabitants, or vnto Strangers, and ≈øhall declare the ≈øame to bee void, and of no force, as by this Treatie of Peace they are declared ≈øo to be; And who≈øoeuer ≈øhall do any thing to the contrary, he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed not only criminally according to the merit of his offence, but ≈øhall al≈øo be compelled to make re≈øtitution, and ≈øatisfaction for the lo≈ø≈øes to the parties damnified, requiring the ≈øame.

div.head: VII.
div.p:
ITem, as concerning the towns of Flu≈øhing, Brill, Ramekins, and other Forts and places thereunto appertaining, in which the garri≈øon Souldiers of the renowned King of England, Scotland, &c. doe now remaine, for as much as the renowned King of England, &c. affirmeth that by contracts heretofore made, betweene Queene ELIZABETH of mo≈øt happie memorie, (vnto whom his Maie≈øtie in his Kingdomes doth ≈øucceed) and the States
of the vnited Prouinces of the low Countreyes, he ≈øtandeth in ≈øuch ≈øort bound, not to redeliuer the ≈øaid Townes, Forts, and places to any others, then vnto tho≈øe who deliuered the ≈øame for Caution, as that by the ≈øaid Contracts, his Maie≈øties Faith, and Honour, (which he re≈øolueth religiou≈øly to keepe towards all per≈øons) being engaged, it is not free for him now to re≈øtore tho≈øe places vnto the Archdukes; yet, in the word of a King, he doeth promi≈øe to enter into Treatie hereafter with the ≈øaid States, wherein his Maie≈øtie will a≈ø≈øigne a competent time vnto them, to accept and receiue Conditions, agreeable to Iu≈øtice, and equitie, for a pacification to be had with the mo≈øt renowned Princes his deare Brethren: which if the States ≈øhall refu≈øe to accept, his Maie≈øtie from thenceforth, as being freed from the former Conuentions, will determine of tho≈øe Townes according as hee ≈øhall iudge it to bee iu≈øt, and honourable, wherein the ≈øaid Princes his louing Brethren, ≈øhall find, that there ≈øhall bee no want in him of tho≈øe good offices which can be expected of a friendly Prince.

div.head: VIII.
div.p: ITem, that the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, &c. will command, as hee ≈øeriou≈øly promi≈øeth ≈øhall be commanded, that his garri≈øon Souldiers vpon what cau≈øe or pretext ≈øoeuer, ≈øhall not ≈øerue, ≈øuccour, victuall, or furni≈øh with Artillerie, Gunpowder, Bullets, Saltpeter, or any other Munition, or a≈øsi≈øtance for Warre, the Hollanders, or other enemies of the King of Spaine, and the Archdukes: neither that they ≈øhall giue vnto them Aide, or doe any ho≈øtile Acte again≈øt the ≈øaid King of Spaine, and Archdukes, or their Subiects: As al≈øo on the part of the King of Spaine, and the Archdukes, no ho≈øtile Acte ≈øhall be committed, or done again≈øt the ≈øaid garri≈øon Souldiers, or again≈øt the mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. or his Subiects.

div.head: IX.
div.p:
ITtem, it is agreed and accorded, that betweene the mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland, &c: and the mo≈øt renowned
King of Spaine, &c. and euery of their Va≈ø≈øals, Inhabitants, and Subiects, as well by Land, as Sea, and fre≈øh Waters, in all and ≈øinguler their Kingdomes, Dominions, I≈ølands, and other Lands, Cities, Townes, Villages, Hauens, & Streights of the ≈øaid Kingdomes, and Dominions, there be, or may bee free Commerce, in which before the Warres there hath bene Commerce, like, and according to the v≈øe and ob≈øeruance of the ancient Leagues, and Treati≈øes, before the Warre, in ≈øuch ≈øort, and manner, as that without any ≈øafeconduct, or other Licence generall, or ≈øpeciall, the Subiects of the one, or other King may freely, a≈øwell by Land as by Sea, and fre≈øh Waters, goe, enter, and ≈øaile, in and to the ≈øaid Kingdomes, and Dominions, and all the Cities, Hauens, Shores, Sea rodes, and Streights thereof and put them≈øelues into what≈øoeuer Hauens of the ≈øame, where before the Warre there hath bene Commerce, like, and according to the v≈øe, and ob≈øeruance of the ancient Leagues, and Treati≈øes before the Warres, with Carriages, Hor≈øes, Burdens, Ships a≈øwell laden, as to bee laden, to
bring in Merchandizes, and there to buy, or ≈øell as much as they will, and in the ≈øame places vpon iu≈øt prices to procure, and haue proui≈øion of Victuals for their ≈øu≈øtenance, and Voyages, and likewi≈øe as occa≈øion ≈øhall require, to repaire ≈øuch ≈øhipping and carriages, as either appertaine vnto them in propertie, or el≈øe they haue hired or borowed, and from thence al≈øo with their Merchandizes, Goods, and other commodities what≈øoeuer, (the Cu≈øtomes, and Tolles, as they are pre≈øently rated according to the Ordinances of the places being paid) they may with like freedome depart, and goe to their owne Countreyes, or any other places at their plea≈øure without let or impediment.

div.head: X.
div.p:
ITem, it is likewi≈øe agreed and accorded, that it may bee lawfull, to haue acce≈ø≈øe vnto the Ports of the ≈øaid Princes, and there to make ≈øtay, and from thence with the ≈øame libertie to depart, not onely with their Ships of Merchandi≈øes, and burthen, but al≈øo with other ≈øhipping furni≈øhed for Warre, and prepared
to with≈øtand the force of enemies: Whether they ≈øhall arriue there, either by force of tempe≈øt, or for repairing their Ships, or for proui≈øion of victuals, ≈øo as they exceed not the number of ≈øixe, or eight Ships, when they come in of their owne accord, nor that they continue, nor make ≈øtay in the Hauens, or about the Ports longer then they ≈øhall haue iu≈øt cau≈øe for the repaire of the ≈øame ≈øhipping, or for proui≈øion of other nece≈ø≈øaries, le≈øt they ≈øhould bee any occa≈øion of Interruption vnto the free Commerce and entercour≈øe of other friends and Nations in amitie: And when≈øoeuer any greater number of Ships of warre then is before ≈øpecified, ≈øhal haue occa≈øion of acce≈ø≈øe into tho≈øe Ports, then ≈øhall it not bee lawfull for them to make any entrance without the priuitie and con≈øent of the Prince. Prouided al≈øo that they doe no ho≈øtile acte, within the ≈øaid Ports, to the preiudice of the Princes, but demeane them≈øelues there quietly, as friends and confederates, with ≈øpeciall Caution euer to bee had, that vnder the colour and pretext of Commerce, no warlike aide, proui≈øion of
victuals, or of armes, or of munition or other ≈øuch like materials for the Warres, be carried by the Subiects, Va≈ø≈øals, or Inhabitants of tho≈øe Kingdomes, to the commoditie or benefit of the enemies of the one or other King. And who≈øoeuer ≈øhall attempt to the contrarie, ≈øhall bee puni≈øhed with tho≈øe ≈øharpe paines and puni≈øhments, v≈øed to be inflicted vpon ≈øeditious per≈øons and breakers of Faith and Peace. Prouided al≈øo, that the Subiects of the one, in the Dominions and Territories of the other, be not wor≈øe handled, then the naturall Subiects in their ≈øales and contracts for their Merchandi≈øes, as wel in re≈øpect of the pri≈øes, as otherwi≈øe, but that the Condition of Forreiners be equal and like herein, vnto natural Subiects: Notwith≈øtanding any Statutes or Cu≈øtomes to the contrarie.

div.head: XI.
div.p:
ITem, it is agreed and accorded, that the mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland &c. ≈øhall prohibite, and after the confirming of the≈øe pre≈øent Articles, by Proclamation forthwith prouide, that no one of his
Subiects, Inhabitants, or Va≈ø≈øals ≈øhall lade, or carie ouer by any meanes directly, or indirectly in his owne name, or in the name of any others, neither ≈øhall lend his Ship or other ve≈ø≈øell for carriage, or v≈øe his name for the tran≈øporting or conueying of any Ships, Merchandi≈øes, Manufactures, or any other thing, out of Holland, and Zeland into Spaine, or other the Kingdomes and Dominions of the King of Spaine, or the Archdukes, neither ≈øhall carrie in his Ships, any Holland, or Zeland Merchant vnto the ≈øaid Ports, vpon perill of his Maie≈øties indignation, and other puni≈øhments v≈øually inflicted on the contemners of his Highne≈ø≈øe commandements. And to the effect that fraude (which through the likene≈ø≈øe of Merchandi≈øe might happen) bee the better auoyded: It is al≈øo prouided in this pre≈øent Article, that the Merchandi≈øes to be carried, and conueyed out of England, Scotland, and Ireland, to the Kingdomes and Dominions of the King of Spaine and Archdukes, ≈øhall bee Regi≈øtred and Sealed with the Seale of the Towne or Citie from whence they ≈øhall bee laden, and
that they being ≈øo Regi≈øtred and Sealed, ≈øhal without any difficultie or que≈øtion what≈øoeuer, bee reputed, and held for Engli≈øh, Scotti≈øh, and Iri≈øh Merchandi≈øes, and ≈øo re≈øpectiuely according to the Seale or Marke, bee allowed and admitted: Alwayes excepted, that in ca≈øe of fraude, proofe ≈øhall be admitted, without ≈øtay notwith≈øtanding or let of the cour≈øe or venting of the Merchandi≈øes in the meane time: And touching ≈øuch Merchandi≈øes, as ≈øhall not be Regi≈øtred nor Sealed, the ≈øame are to bee Confi≈øcated and taken for good Prize: And likewi≈øe all Hollanders and Zelanders, which ≈øhall bee found in the ≈øame Ships, may al≈øo bee taken and detained.

div.head: XII.
div.p:
ITem, it is agreed that Engli≈øh, Scotti≈øh, and Iri≈øh Merchandi≈øes may be conueyed, and tran≈øported out of England, Scotland, and Ireland into Spaine, and other of the Kingdomes of the King of Spaine, (before mentioned) without the payment of the Impo≈øition of thirtie in the hundred, lately impo≈øed;
but paying onely the Cu≈øtome and Tolles v≈øually required, before the ≈øaid Impo≈øition of thirtie in the hundred.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
ITem, it is likewi≈øe agreed, that for the Merchandi≈øes. which Engli≈øh, Scotti≈øh, and Iri≈øh Merchants ≈øhall buy in Spaine, or other the Kingdomes of the ≈øayd King of Spaine, and ≈øhall carrie in their owne Ships, or in Ships hired, or lent vnto them (except as before hath bene ≈øaid the Ships of Hollanders and Zelanders) they ≈øhall pay onely ≈øuch Tolles as were accu≈øtomed to bee paide before the Impo≈øition of thirtie in the hundred, yet ≈øo as they conuey and carrie the ≈øame goods and Merchandi≈øes to the Kingdomes of the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland &c. or to the Ports of the Prouinces, being in obedience to the Archdukes. And for the more ≈øuretie that fraude bee not committed herein, and that the ≈øaid Merchandi≈øes bee not tran≈øported to other places and Kingdomes, and e≈øpecially into Holland or Zeland, it is concluded, that the
≈øaid Merchants ≈øhall binde them≈øelues, at the time that they doe lade their Ships in Spaine, or in the other Kingdomes and Dominions of the ≈øaid King of Spaine aboue declared, before the Magi≈øtrate of the place in which they ≈øhall lade, to pay the ≈øaid Impo≈øition of thirtie in the hundred, in ca≈øe they carrie the ≈øame goods and Merchandi≈øes to other Dominions and Countries: And to obtaine al≈øo within the ≈øpace of twelue moneths following, a Certificate from the Magi≈øtrate of the places, where they ≈øhall di≈øcharge or vnlade the ≈øame goods, te≈øtifying their di≈øcharge to haue beene either in the Kingdomes and Dominions of the King of England &c. or in the Ports of the Prouinces vnder the obedience of the ≈øaid Archdukes: vpon the exhibiting whereof, the Obligations concerning tho≈øe matters ≈øhall be deliuered vp, vnto the bringers of the ≈øame Certificates.

div.head: XIIII.
div.p:
ANd al≈øo that the ≈øayd mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, &c. ≈øhall prohibite ≈øoone after
the confirming of this accord, that none ≈øhall exporte any merchandize out of Spaine, or other Kingdomes of the King of Spaine, to be caried to other places then to his Maie≈øties Kingdomes, and the ≈øayd Portes of Flanders, vpon penaltie of confi≈øcation of all their merchandi≈øes, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid King of England, &c. to be paide into his Maie≈øties Exchequer: of which merchandi≈øes, or the value thereof, one halfe is to bee giuen to the Informer, (the impo≈øition of thirtie in the hundred being fir≈øt deducted) to bee payed to the Mini≈øters and Deputies of the King of Spaine, and the proofes lawfully receiued in Spaine, and tran≈ømitted into England in authenticall fourme, are to bee credited.

div.head: XV.
div.p:
ITem, that the Magi≈øtrates of the ≈øayde townes or Cities of his Maie≈øties Kingdomes, which ≈øhall make Certificates of the vnlading of ≈øhippes, and are to giue te≈øtimony of the regi≈øtring of the merchandi≈øes, ≈øhal not commit any fraud therein, vnder
perill of indignation of the Kings Maie≈øtie, and paine of lo≈ø≈øe of their offices, and other more grieuous puni≈øhments at the Kings plea≈øure. This declaration being added, that when the King of Spaine and Archdukes ≈øhall agree with the French King, or with any other vpon the la≈øt Placard of thirty in the hundred, and the Commerce betwixt them be re≈øtored, then it ≈øhall bee lawfull to the Subiects of the ≈øayd mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland, &c. to tran≈øport their merchandi≈øes to the Kingdomes and Dominions of him, or them vnto whom Commerce ≈øhall be re≈øtored without the payment of thirty in the hundred, but onely paying the Tolles and Cu≈øtomes v≈øed and payed before the ≈øayd impo≈øition.

div.head: XVI.
div.p:
THat which hath before been expre≈ø≈øed, concerning the free Commerce granted vnto the Subiects of the ≈øaid renowned kings, is to be vnder≈øtood to bee likewi≈øe agreed on, for the Subiects of the mo≈øt renowned King & Princes, the king of England,
Scotland, France and Ireland, &c. and the Archdukes, to wit, that in all places what≈øoeuer, their Subiects are bound reciprocally, to re≈øpect & to fauour ech other, and by mutuall kinde offices friendly to intertaine the one the other, and that by land, ≈øea, and fre≈øh waters, without any ≈øafe conduct or other licence generall or ≈øpeciall, they may vnto the ≈øaide Kingdomes, Dominions, Lands, Villages, Towns, Cities, Sea ≈øhores, Hauens, Sea rodes what≈øoeuer, freely, ≈øafely, ≈øecurely, come, enter, ≈øayle, carie and recarie their merchandi≈øes, buy, and ≈øell, remaine, abide, and conuer≈øe in the ≈øame, ≈øo long as it ≈øhall plea≈øe them, any kinde of proui≈øion for victuall, and things nece≈ø≈øary for ≈øu≈øtenance, and for voiages at iu≈øt & rea≈øonable prices, and there repaire al≈øo (as occa≈øion ≈øhall require) their ≈øhipping, and cariages, whether the ≈øame be their owne, or whether they be hired or borrowed: As al≈øo to depart from thence with like libertie, with merchandi≈øes, goods, and other things what≈øoeuer (the Cu≈øtomes and Tolles according to the Statutes of tho≈øe places being payd) and to di≈øpo≈øe and follow
their bu≈øine≈ø≈øes freely, and to returne at their owne plea≈øure, either into their owne Countreys, or to any other place, without any impediment or let, ≈øo as the Subiects of the mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. v≈øe not the ≈øhipping of the Hollanders, or the vnited Prouinces, and bring not into the Prouinces of the Archdukes any of the manufactures of Holland, or of the vnited Prouinces bought where≈øoeuer, neither any other thing, for which there was paid in Holland any tribute, nor that they tran≈øport any thing from the Archdukes Prouinces, vnto them of tho≈øe Prouinces vntill a pacification be accorded: Nor that they receiue any the goods or Hollanders, or of tho≈øe other places vnited into their ≈øhips, nor tru≈øt any of their owne goods in the ≈øhips of Hollanders, nor fraudulently by lending their names, colour the goods of any Hollander, or other of the vnited Prouinces: for that if any thing be committed to the contrary, and the ≈øame be found, it ≈øhall bee held for iu≈øt and lawfull Price.

div.head: XVII.
div.p:
ANd the afore≈øaid Proui≈øoes are not only to bee vnder≈øtood of ≈øhips laden or to be laden in cau≈øe of Commerce, but al≈øo of ≈øhippes of Warre which the ≈øaid Princes haue or ≈øhall haue armed to repre≈ø≈øe the Attempts of their Enemies: in≈øomuch as that it may be lawfull for ≈øuch Ships of warre, not exceeding the number before mentioned, if they happen to be con≈øtrained either by force of tempe≈øt, or for buying of Victuals or other things, or for repaire of ≈øhipping, to v≈øe the ≈øame libertie in arriuing, ≈øtaying, and departing: ≈øo that they doe no Ho≈øtile acte in the ≈øaid Ports, but demeane them≈øelues hone≈øtly and quietly, as it becommeth confederates and friends: and ≈øo that they ≈øtay and remaine not in, or about the ≈øame Ports any longer then ≈øhall bee needfull for reparation and proui≈øion of nece≈ø≈øaries, that thereby they be not a hinderance or interruption to the free Commerce and Entercour≈øe with other Nations that are in Amitie and Friend≈øhip: but where occa≈øion ≈øhall fall out of arriuall
of any greater number of Shipping then before ≈øpecified, it ≈øhall not bee lawfull for them to enter, but with the knowledge and allowance of the Prince.

div.head: XVIII.
div.p: ANd as the ≈øaide Kings and Archdukes doe religiou≈øly promi≈øe, that they will not at any time yeeld any Warlike ≈øuccour to any of the others enemies, ≈øo it is prouided that their Subiects, or the inhabitants in their Realmes, of what nation or qualitie ≈øoeuer they be, may not vnder colour of Entercour≈øe and Commerce, nor vpon any other colour or pretence giue any ayde or helpe to the enemies of the ≈øayd Princes, or of either of them, or conferre, or ≈øupplie them with money, proui≈øions of victuals for warre, Amour, Municion, Ordinance, Artillerie, or other warlike proui≈øion, and tho≈øe which ≈øhall do the contrary, are to take knowledge, that they ≈øhall bee puni≈øhed with the ≈øeuere puni≈øhments accu≈øtomed to be inflicted vpon breakers of League, and ≈øeditious per≈øons.

div.head: XIX.
div.p: AND that al≈øo greater benefite may through this Concord come vnto the Subiects of the mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland, &c. and of the Archdukes, it is accorded and concluded, that the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. and Archdukes ioyntly and ≈øeuerally, will doe their endeuours, that their Subiects haue not the pa≈ø≈øages ≈øtopped or letted vnto any of their Ports, Kingdomes and Dominions, that thereby they bee not hindered, freely and without impediment to come and goe, with their Shipping, Merchandi≈øe, and Carriages (the ordinarie Cu≈øtomes and Tolles being paide) to al the ≈øaid Ports, Kingdomes, and Dominions: and with the like libertie (when it ≈øhall ≈øeeme ≈øo good vnto them) with other Merchandi≈øes from thence to depart.

div.head: XX.
div.p:
BVt as concerning the ancient Treati≈øes of entercour≈øe and Commerce, whereof diuers are extant, betwixt the Kingdomes
of England, Scotland, and Ireland, and the Dominions of the Dukes of Burgundie, and Princes of the Low Countreyes, which notwith≈øtanding during the late troubles haue beene intermitted, and peraduenture in ≈øome parts impaired; it is agreed by way of proui≈øion, That they ≈øhall retaine and haue their auncient forte and authoritie, and that they ≈øhall bee v≈øed on both parts, as they were before the Warres: And if it happen that either by both partes or any one part any breach thereof be alleadged, or that the Subiects ≈øhall complaine that the Conuentions are not ob≈øerued, or that more grieuous burdens then were accu≈øtomed are impo≈øed on them, there ≈øhall bee Deputies appointed on either part which may meete, and calling vnto them (if neede be) Merchants experienced in ≈øuch matters, may friendly Treate, and equally renew, and re≈øtore ≈øuch things, as ≈øhal bee founde either to haue ≈ølipped out of cour≈øe, or to haue beene changed by the injurie of time, or by corrupt cu≈øtome and v≈øe.

div.head: XXI.
div.p: ANd for that the rights of Commerce which doe en≈øue by Peace ought not to be made vnfruitfull, as they would be if the Subiects of the mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland &c. while≈øt they haue recour≈øe to and from the Kingdomes and Dominions of the ≈øaid King of Spaine and Archdukes, and do remaine there for Commerce, ≈øhould bee mole≈øted in the cau≈øe of Con≈øcience: therefore to the intent their Traffique may be ≈øafe, and without danger, as well on Land as on Sea, the ≈øaid renowned King of Spaine, and Archdukes ≈øhall take care, and prouide, that for the ≈øaid cau≈øe of Con≈øcience they ≈øhall not be mole≈øted, nor inquieted in v≈øing their Trade and Commerce, ≈øo as they giue not ≈øcandall vnto others.

div.head: XXII.
div.p:
ITem, that if it happen any goods or Merchandi≈øes prohibited to be carried, or conueyed out of the Kingdomes and Dominions of the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned Kings and
Archdukes, by the Subiects of the one or of the other, that in ≈øuch ca≈øe the per≈øon onely offending ≈øhall incurre puni≈øhment, and the goods onely prohibited ≈øhalbe Confi≈øcated.

div.head: XXIII.
div.p: ITem, that the goods of the Subiects dying within the Kingdomes or Dominions of either, ≈øhall be con≈øerued to the right heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øours of the decea≈øed, the right of a third Per≈øon alwayes re≈øerued.

div.head: XXIIII.
div.p: ITem, that the Graunts and Priueledges giuen by the Princes to Merchants of either of the Kingdomes comming to their ≈øaid Kingdomes, and which Priueledges through the Warres haue cea≈øed, ≈øhall from henceforth wholly bee reuiued and haue their full force and ≈øtrength.

div.head: XXV.
div.p:
ITem, if it ≈øhall happen hereafter, (which God forbid) that any di≈øplea≈øure doe ari≈øe, betweene the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned Kings,
the King of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, &c. And the King of Spaine, or the Archdukes, whereby danger might grow of the interruption of entercour≈øe and Commerce, then the Subiects of either Prince are thereof ≈øo to be admoni≈øhed, as that they may haue ≈øixe Moneths from the time of the monition, to tran≈øport their Merchandi≈øes without any arre≈øt, di≈øturbance, or hurt in the meane ≈øea≈øon, to be done or giuen vnto them either in their per≈øons or Merchandi≈øes.

div.head: XXVI.
div.p: ITem, that none of the fore≈øayd Princes ≈øhall imbarge or ≈øtay for their proui≈øion in warre, or for any other ≈øeruice, to the preiudice of the owners, the ≈øhips of the Subiects of any of the others, being in their Ports, or waters, vnle≈ø≈øe the Prince of tho≈øe parties to whom the ≈øhips doe appertaine, ≈øhall fir≈øt be admoni≈øhed thereof, and ≈øhall al≈øo yeeld his con≈øent thereunto.

div.head: XXVII.
div.p:
ITem, it is accorded, that if during this Peace and Amitie, any thing happen to be
attempted, committed or done, again≈øt the force and effect thereof, by land, ≈øea, or fre≈øh waters, either by any of the ≈øaid Princes their Heires and Succe≈ø≈øors, their Va≈ø≈øals, Subiects, or Allies comprehended in this League, or of any the Heires or Succe≈ø≈øours of tho≈øe Allies their Subiects, or Va≈ø≈øals, yet notwith≈øtanding this Peace and Amitie, ≈øhal remaine in his ≈øtrength and vertue, and the attempters, and ≈øuch as doe offend therein onely, and no other, ≈øhall bee puni≈øhed for their attempts.

div.head: XXVIII.
div.p: ITem, that ≈øuch as haue beene taken in warre, and are Captiues on either part, although they be condemned to the Galleys ≈øhall be relea≈øed and di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, the charges of the diet of ≈øuch as are not in the Galleys being fir≈øt di≈øcharged, and the ran≈øomes of ≈øuch as haue before agreed for the ≈øame, being by them payed.

div.head: XXIX.
div.p:
ITem, it is concluded, that all ciuill actions, which at the time when the la≈øt warres began, were of validitie, and of force, may
yet bee exerci≈øed and pur≈øued, notwith≈øtanding any lap≈øe of time during the ≈øame war, ≈øo as no preiudice ≈øhall bee vnder≈øtood to haue growen vnto them, by the continuance of the warre, tho≈øe onely excepted which are already come to the Exchequer or Princes Trea≈øurie.

div.head: XXX.
div.p: ITem, if any controuer≈øie happen to bee moued in the Kingdomes and Dominions of the one or other of the≈øe Princes, by any per≈øon not being Subiect to the ≈øame Prince, for, or vpon occa≈øion of any depredations or ≈øpoyles committed, the cau≈øe is to be remitted to the Iudge of the iuri≈ødiction, vnder that Prince again≈øt who≈øe Subiect or Subiects the ≈øuite is commenced.

div.head: XXXI.
div.p:
ITem, that if the Hollanders and other confederate States, will accept of conditions of pacification with the mo≈øt renowned Archdukes, or their Succe≈ø≈øors, through the meanes of the mo≈øt renowned king of England, &c. the ≈øayd Archdukes and their Succe≈ø≈øors,
will alwayes willingly hearken vnto that which ≈øhal be propo≈øed therein, and will de≈øire that by the helpe of the ≈øayd mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. they may bee brought to embrace equall coÃÑditions, wherin they ≈øhal wel vnder≈øtand, how much the ≈øaid Archdukes doe attribute vnto the authority of the mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. their louing brother.

div.head: XXXII.
div.p:
ITem, it is concluded and accorded, that in this pre≈øent Treatie of peace, there bee comprehended the Adherents, friends, and confederats, of the forenamed Princes: That is to ≈øay, on the part of the mo≈øt renowned King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, &c. Rodulphe Romane Emperour, with the Archdukes of Austrice, and the Electors of the Empire, together with the States, and Cities of the Empire, the Duke of Lorrain, the duke of Sauoy, the dukes of Brun≈øwicke, Lunenburg, Meckleburg, Wirtemberg, the Landgraue of He≈øse, the Marque≈ø≈øe of Baden, the duke of Pomerane, the Prince of Anhalt,
the Earle of East-frei≈øland, the Cantons of Heluetia, and the Gri≈øons, the Haun≈øe-cities; The French King, the King of Poland, and Swethland, the King of Denmarke, the duke and State of Venice, the duke of Holst, the duke of Florence.

div.head: XXXIII.
div.p:
ON the part of the King of Spaine and Archdukes, Rodulphe Romane Emperour, and his Brethren, and other Princes, Archdukes of Au≈øtrice, Princes of the Empire, the Electors, Cities, and States ≈øubiect to the Empire, the French King, the King of Poland and Swethland, the King of Denmarke, the duke and State of Venice, the duke of Sauoy, the duke of Bauire, the duke of Cleue, the duke of Hol≈øtein, the duke of Lorraine, the duke of Parma and Placentia, with his Brother, the Cardinall, the Bi≈øhop and Prouince of Liege, the duke of Florence, the duke of Mantua, the duke of Mutina, and Regium, the duke of Vrbine, the Confederats and Cantons of the Heluetians, and Gri≈øons, the Cities of the Haun≈øe, the Earles of Eastfrie≈øland
(without notwith≈øtanding any preiudice of the right by the King of Spaine, and Archdukes pretended for their States) the duke and Common wealth of Genua, the Common wealth of Lukes, the Principall of the Hou≈øe of Columna, the Prince of Oria, the Principall of the hou≈øe of Vr≈øine, the duke of Sermoneta, the Lord of Monacho, the Earle of Mirandula, the Marques of Ma≈ø≈øa, the Earle of Sala, the Earle of Colorno.

div.head: XXXIIII.
div.p:
ITem, it is likewi≈øe accorded and concluded, that the ≈øaide mo≈øt renowned Kings and Princes, IAMES by the grace of God King of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, &c. And PHILIP King of Spaine, &c. Albert and I≈øabella Clara Eugenia, Archdukes, &c. ≈øhall ≈øincerely, and faithfully ob≈øerue and keepe, and procure to be ob≈øerued and kept, by their Subiects, and Inhabitants, all and ≈øinguler the Capitulations in this pre≈øent Treatie accorded, and concluded, neither ≈øhall they directly or indirectly infringe the ≈øame, or con≈øent that the ≈øame ≈øhalbe infringed,
fringed, directly, or indirectly, by any of their Subiects or Inhabitants, and they ≈øhal ratifie, authori≈øe and confirme, all and ≈øingular the Conuentions as before accorded and concluded by Letters Pattents, ≈øub≈øcribed with their owne hands, and ≈øealed with their great Seales in ≈øufficient, auaileable, and effectuall forme, and the ≈øame ≈øo formed and made, ≈øhall vpon the fir≈øt occa≈øion deliuer or cau≈øe to be deliuered faithfully, really, and effectually; And they ≈øhall make the like promi≈øe to ob≈øerue all and ≈øingular the premi≈ø≈øes, in the word of a King and Prince, and ≈øhall al≈øo ≈øweare to ob≈øerue and performe the ≈øame by oath vpon the holy Euangeli≈øt, (when≈øoeuer they ≈øhall, by either part be thereunto required.) And the ≈øaid Kings and Archdukes ≈øhall take care that this pre≈øent Peace and Amitie be publi≈øhed in places accu≈øtomed, ≈øo ≈øoone as conueniently the ≈øame may be.

div.head: ‚ùß Articles concerning Merchandize of high Germanie to be tran≈øported into Spaine, free of the Impo≈øition of 30. in the 100.

div.p:
THE more to expre≈ø≈øe ob≈øeruance towardes the mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. and for the commoditie of his Maie≈øties Kingdomes, the Illu≈øtrious and excellent the Con≈øtable of Ca≈øtile, &c. Procurator ≈øpeciall of his Cath. Maie≈øtie, hearing how much the Subiects of the mo≈øt renowned king of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, doe de≈øire to be permitted to vent the merchandi≈øe of Germanie in Spaine, doeth by the≈øe pre≈øents promi≈øe, that it ≈øhall be lawfull for the ≈øayd Subiects of the mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. to conuey merchandi≈øe out of high Germanie, being ≈øubiect to the Impo≈øition of thirtie in the hundred, and which without payment of the ≈øayd Impo≈øition could not be caried into Spaine, and the ≈øame merchandi≈øe hauing
fir≈øt been conueyed into England, and there di≈øcharged, & cu≈øtomed, from thence after to be tran≈øported into Spaine, or other the Dominions of the King of Spaine, without payment of thirtie in the hundred, ≈øo as the ≈øaid merchandi≈øe hath payd nothing to the Hollanders, and Zelanders, and other enemies of the King of Spaine, and the Archdukes: and ≈øo as they be conueyed in the proper ≈øhips of the mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. or his Subiects, and not in others of any other Prince, or Nation, or of other whome≈øoeuer. And to the effect that fraude herein may bee auoyded, the Merchandi≈øes of high Germanie, which are to bee tran≈øported foorth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, to the Kingdomes and Dominions of the King of Spaine and the Archdukes, ≈øhall bee Regi≈øtred and marked with the Seale or Marke of the Towne from whence they ≈øhall bee laden, and certified by a Certificate from the Magi≈øtrate of the ≈øaid Towne or Citie, te≈øtifying that the ≈øaid Merchandi≈øes were di≈øcharged in England, Scotland or Ireland, and that they haue paide Cu≈øtome there, as well vpon perill
of the Kings Maie≈øties indignation, as al≈øo vpon paine of lo≈ø≈øe of their Offices and other more grieuous puni≈øhments, to bee inflicted at the Kings plea≈øure, vpon the Magi≈øtrates of the Townes and Cities of the Kingdomes, of the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned King of England, &c. which are to certifie the vnlading of Ships, and to te≈øtifie of the Regi≈øtring thereof, if they ≈øhall herein commit any fraude.

div.head: II.
div.p: ITem, that what≈øoeuer merchandizes of high Germany, ≈øhall not bee di≈øcharged in England, Scotland and Ireland, and yet ≈øhall be conueyed into Spaine, and other Kingdoms of the King of Spaine as ≈øuch merchandi≈øes, ≈øhall be confi≈øcated, and bee reputed as good Prize.

div.head: ¬∂ Three Articles concerning a moderation to be had in the proceedings of the Inqui≈øition, toward the Kings Maie≈øties Subiects, in SPAINE.

div.p: FIr≈øt, if they haue exceeded in any thing before their entrance into Spaine, they ≈øhall not be called into the INQVISITION for the ≈øame, neither ≈øhall bee mole≈øted for any of tho≈øe things ≈øo committed, out of Spaine, neither ≈øhall any Account for the ≈øame bee demaunded of them.

div.head: II.
div.p: AL≈øo if they will not enter into the Churches, no man ≈øhall compell them thereunto, but if they doe enter into the ≈øame, they ≈øhall performe tho≈øe dueties & reuerence, which are v≈øed towards the holy Sacrament of the Altar being there, and if they ≈øhall ≈øee the holy Sacrament comming towards them in any ≈øtreete, they ≈øhall doe reuerence by bowing their knees, or el≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe a≈øide by ≈øome other ≈øtreete, or turne into ≈øome hou≈øe.

div.head: III.
div.p: ANd if any of the ≈øaid per≈øons being Ma≈øters, or Ma≈øters Mates, or any other Officers of ≈øhips, which bee not their owne, doe exceed in any matter herein, the INQVISITION proceeding again≈øt them by Office, is onely to ≈øeque≈øter their owne proper goods, and are to leaue free the ≈øhips and all other goods not belonging to the Offenders; the ≈øame is to be vnder≈øtood for the Traders and Factors.
